title-group.article-title: A review of experimental studies on deposits in the combustion chambers of internal combustion engines

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory of Engines, Tianjin University, People’s Republic of China
2Research Institute of Petroleum, General Logistics Department of PLA, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Xingyu Liang, State Key Laboratory of Engines, Tianjin University, No. 92, Weijin Road, Tianjin, People’s Republic of China. Email: lxy@tju.edu.cn

abstract.p: This article reviews experimental studies on deposits in engine combustion chambers, with emphasis on deposit composition, damage to engines, formation mechanisms and study methods. The existence of combustion chamber deposits will definitely influence performance and emissions of engines, and is inevitable with the use of petroleum fuel and lubricating oil. These all make it necessary to study the formation, composition, structure and influential factors of deposits, which will provide the basis for reducing deposits in engines. Influential factors and methods of reducing deposit formation are also included. First, the deposit damage to engines is briefly introduced, with a focus mainly on the decline in engine performance and the deterioration of emissions, and the reasons for these phenomena are explained. Next, conclusions on deposit research approaches to their chemical composition and physical structure are drawn. Finally, with regards to deposit formation in gasoline and diesel engines, deposit composition and factors influencing deposit formation, such as engine type, fuel type, oil type, additives, exhaust gas recirculation, etc., are enumerated through experimental studies on engines. Studies on deposit formation with some newly developed types of fuel are also included. The mechanism of deposit formation under these different conditions is explained, and the methods for reducing deposit formation are summarized.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The existence of combustion chamber deposits (CCDs) definitely influences the performance and emissions of engines, and is inevitable with the use of petroleum fuel and lubricating oil. The deposits may cause unfavorable effects on exhaust emissions in various ways. With regards to NOx emissions, the deposits tend to lead to increased emissions.1–3 Statistically, a significant increase is observed in NOx emissions with an increase in deposit thickness.4 The low thermal conductivity of deposits, especially non-volatile deposits such as ash, produces higher in-cylinder temperatures, thus leading to higher NOx emissions.1 Higher hydrocarbon (HC) emissions is also observed with an increase in engine deposits,1,5–7 and extra HC emissions due to deposit accumulation accounts for 10–20% of the total HC emissions.8 CO emissions of engines can also be obviously influenced by the increase and decrease of deposits.6 Adsorption and desorption of hydrocarbons by the porous deposits are considered to be the major causes for the undesirable increase in HC emissions.9

Engine performance can also be greatly affected by deposits. It is easy to understand that the existence of deposits will diminish the volume of the combustion chamber, which will lead to a change in the nominal compression ratio, thus influencing the normal combustion of engines. Uncontrolled surface ignition, resulting from deposit-created hot spots, can lead to knocking, run-on and rumble.1 The heat regeneration and thermal insulation effects of deposits will also result in an increase of octane demand.10 Another effect caused by the deposits in engines is diesel knock, whose tendency increases rapidly with deposit accumulation.11

On the other hand, excessive deposits may impair engine performance, and even cause engine failure.12–14 For example, the excessive deposits in a piston ring groove may cause the piston rings to stick and may cause cylinder scoring. The flaked deposits from the combustion chamber may cause difficulties in start-up and poor drivability of engines.

sec.title: Existence of deposits
sec.p: Deposits are widely formed on the combustion chamber surfaces of various combustion devices, such as boilers, furnaces, burners and engines. This article mainly focuses on the deposits in the combustion chamber of internal combustion engines.

Deposits exist in engines once petroleum fuel and lubricating oil are used. For this reason, the study of engine deposits proceeds with the development of engine technologies. In 1925, Orelup studied the factors influencing carbon formation in engines, and took a picture of the deposits on the surface of the cylinder head. After that, many researchers in various countries conducted studies on the deposits. Kalghatgi wrote two reviews on the deposits in gasoline engines.15,16 Although some differences exist in the two reviews, deposit structure, properties, influencing factors of deposit formation and the ways to control deposit formation were included in both reviews. As for the composition of deposits, it is thought, in general, that inorganic substances, carbon granules and oxidized products of organics are the main components of the deposits.17

Following early studies by Nishiwaki18 and Hayes et al.,19 Nishiwaki and Hafnan investigated the thermal conductivity and thermal diffusivity of the deposits in diesel and gasoline engines.20 One diesel engine with a stroke of 90 mm and a bore of 94 mm and one gasoline engine with a stroke of 79 mm and a bore of 66 mm were used to conduct the experiments.

The physical properties of deposits from gasoline and diesel engines in different parts are shown in Table 1. The values in the table show the differences in deposits in different engine types and different positions in the engines. The differences between the physical properties of deposits from gasoline and diesel engines may arise from the difference in combustion chamber sizes, load, speed, fuel types and oil types. As for the volatility of deposits, Owrang showed that up to 50% of the deposits, formed inside a gasoline direct injection (GDI) engine, consisted of volatiles, and the composition of the deposits was strongly related to the composition of the engine oil.21

caption.p: Thermal conductivity and thermal diffusivity of the deposits. (Reprinted with permission SAE paper 2000-01-1215 copyright © 2000 SAE International.)20

sec.p: Although formed in many parts of the engine, deposits formed on the piston top and the cylinder head surface attract the most attention because of their large influences on combustion through the increased compression ratio and increased surface temperature. Deposits on nozzles, piston ring grooves, piston lands and valves have also been studied.12,22–24 For example, Diaby et al. found that the deposits in the first ring grooves of the diesel engine investigated were mainly carbonaceous and resulted principally from the lubricant degradation.23 Haji-Sulaiman and Mat-Isa found that gasoline doped with a trace amount of used engine oil exhibited a high intake-valve deposit-forming tendency in their simulated study.24 All these studies also showed that the lubricating oil played an important role in deposit formation.

The mechanism of deposit formation in the engine cylinders is quite complex. Many factors, such as the types of fuel and lubricating oil, in-cylinder gas temperature and pressure, cooling water temperature and the size of engines, govern the formation of deposits. For example, Eilts mentioned that an effective reduction of deposit formation is possible by increasing the compression ratio, the charge air and exhaust gas pressure.25 However, the thickness of deposits does not increase without limit, and reaches an equilibrium thickness after a long period of operation.26 The reasons may arise from the evaporation, burning and degradation of deposits or flaking from the surface. When analyzing the disappearance of deposits, the most direct method is to refer to the results of thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA). TGA curves of the deposits under oxygen and nitrogen atmospheres indicate that most of the deposits are evaporated, oxidized or burned because of the high temperature in the combustion chamber. Substances that are hard to oxidize or are not volatile accumulate on the surface of the combustion chamber, and thus deposits are formed. The remaining deposits can possibly flake off the surface of the combustion chamber,14 thus achieving equilibrium of deposit loading.

sec.title: Deposit study methods
sec.p: The most direct and easiest method of deposit investigation is the photographic observation of deposits.27–29 Weighing the deposits directly scraped from the combustion chamber walls is also employed frequently. The composition and microstructure of deposits require further study and understanding. Some of the most commonly used methods are described below.

sec.title: Thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA)
sec.p: TGA is widely used in many fields to investigate the pyrolysis and the rules of weight loss according to the temperature change. Using the TGA, different components of the deposits can be separated by temperature.23,28,30 Volatile content is evaporated by thermal decomposition from the deposit sample in TGA under non-oxidative conditions. The contents of carbon and other impurities will be obtained under an oxidative environment. Figure 1 show a typical TGA result under different conditions.31 In the figure, OD is the ordinary diesel fuel, and crude palm oil (CPO) and its emulsions with 1%, 2% and 3% water (CPO99, CPO98 and CPO97, respectively) are shown. Weight loss with temperature change can be seen clearly from the figure, demonstrating the effectiveness of TGA in studying the composition of deposits.

caption.p: Deposit weight loss with temperature: (a) N2 purge and (b) O2 purge (source: reproduced with permission from Elsevier, reference 31).
CPO: crude palm oil; OD: ordinary diesel fuel.

sec.title: Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) analysis
sec.p: FTIR analysis is widely used in many fields for its convenience in the analysis of characteristics and chemical functionality of samples. For deposits, comparison of different deposits and influencing factors can be achieved by FTIR analysis.29Figure 2 shows the typical spectra of deposits.23 The curves indicate the difference between deposits and %T means absorbance. B, C and D are the different operating times. The band near 2900 cm−1 was attributed to alkyl C–H vibrations. The bands that appeared in the 1700 cm−1 region were attributed to the C=O carbonyl vibrations of oxidation products. The detail of the deposit composition change with engine operation can be achieved from infrared spectra, thus FTIR is indispensable in deposit researches.

caption.p: Infrared spectra of the first ring groove deposits (source: reproduced with permission from Elsevier, reference 23).

sec.title: Chemical composition analysis
sec.p: Chemical analysis, which is the most direct method of investigating the composition of samples, is also used in the study of deposit processes. By analyzing compositions of deposits, detailed composition of deposits can be achieved. It is of great importance to identify the source of deposits.29

Many other methods are also used in studying the composition of deposits, such as X-ray dispersive energy analysis23 and X-ray diffractograms.32 All these are good supplementary means to understanding the details of deposit composition.

sec.title: Structure studies
sec.p: When considering the position and the porous structure of deposits, it is meaningful to know the detailed structure of the deposits. It is necessary to study the surface morphology and inner porous structure. Much research has been carried out on the structure of deposits, and a great deal of detail has been achieved for further understanding deposits.33–36

sec.title: Electron microscopes
sec.p: As a newly developed technology, electron microscopes have made great contributions in many fields. The most commonly used are scanning electron microscopes (SEMs)23 and transmission electron microscopy (TEM).9 For deposits, surface morphology can be achieved from the results of electron microscopes. Figure 3 and Figure 4 show typical results of TEM and SEMs. Clear surface morphology of deposits can be seen from the results of the SEM. Figure 4(a) shows a cracked varnish aspect for the deposits. The surface seemed to be polished by the movements of the ring in the groove. Figure 4(b) shows the cross-section of the deposits. It is meaningful to investigate the influencing factors of deposit formation.

caption.p: A typical transmission electron micrograph of a combustion engine deposit (source: reproduced with permission from Elsevier, reference 9).
(a) A front view of the first ring deposits and (b) the ring tilted at 70° for the engine test B (source: reproduced with permission from Elsevier, reference 23).

sec.title: Gas absorption
sec.p: It is difficult to observe the inner porous structure of deposits from the surface. Absorption is the most commonly used method to study the inner structure of samples, and it is widely used in studying the inner structure of deposits.9,30,37 For deposits, inner surface area, pore sizes and other parameters can be achieved by absorption. Figure 5 shows a typical absorption result.9 The six curves show the adsorption and desorption of N2 and CO2. Open symbols show adsorption and closed symbols show desorption. The differences among the curves arise from the processes of adsorption and desorption.

caption.p: Gas sorption isotherms on engine deposit (source: reproduced with permission from Elsevier, reference 9).

sec.title: Raman spectra
sec.p: Raman spectra are widely used in analyzing the structure of molecules, as no sample pretreatment is required, which avoids some errors. For deposits, Raman spectra can characterize graphitic nano-crystallites presented in combustion deposits. In this way, the influencing factors of deposit formation can be compared.30Figure 6 shows a typical Raman spectra result.9 The dashed line is the best fit of the experimental curve to a sum of two Gaussian components, which are shown as solid lines. The proportion of the two peaks in the curves shows the graphitization degree of deposits. The total intensities of the two Raman bands are centered at about 1590 cm−1and 1350 cm−1, and the band near 1590 cm−1 is the characteristic spectral line of graphite.

caption.p: Raman spectrum of sample (source: reproduced with permission from Elsevier, reference 9).

sec.p: Many other means are also used in deposit structure research, e.g. mercury porosimetry,9 X-ray diffractograms,32 X-ray dispersion23 and Mossbauer absorption,32 and all of these serve as good supplements in understanding the structure of deposits.
Through the structure study methods mentioned above, accompanied by composition studies, deposit characteristics can be studied, and the basis for deposit reduction provided.

sec.title: Deposit formation
sec.p: Much research has been carried out on the formation and composition of deposits. Although the conclusions vary according to the conditions of the experiments, deposit formation is basically governed by the type of fuel and lubricating oil and the engine operating conditions. Research on deposit formation on diesel and gasoline engines is discussed briefly below.

For deposits in gasoline engines, Kalghatgi illustrated that the deposits formed in the engines and, as the deposits continued to grow and insulate the cooler metal substrate, the deposit surface temperature rose and deposit material of lower volatility and higher melting point could be observed.15 Zerda et al. suggested that the main cause of deposits formed in engines was the incomplete combustion of fuel and thermal cracking of the lubricating oil.9 Price et al.38 and Uehara et al.39 showed that aromatic hydrocarbons and hydrocarbons with higher flash points in fuels were the key components of deposits in the combustion chamber, and furthermore, deposits in engines were oxidative condensation polymers of aromatic hydrocarbons. For the formation process and its influencing factors, Cheng pointed out that a porous, solid crust was formed over the dense viscous liquid, on the bottom layer, causing the formation of a large thermal gradient between hot combustion gases and the cool metal surface of combustion chamber.40 Güralp et al. found that the thickness of deposits was closely related to surface temperature.41

For deposits in diesel engines, Eilts found that the combination of low wall temperature and unburned fuel causes more deposit formation in combustion chambers.25 Shurvell et al. thought that deposits or carbon deposits might be defined as a heterogeneous mixture made up of carbon residue (ash), carbonaceous mixtures (soot) and oxygenated resinous organic materials that bind together as mixtures.42 Gebhard et al. suggested that initial deposits on the cool chamber metal basement mainly consisted of volatile materials that were difficult to oxidize, with a low melting point and contained more carbon.37

In diesel engines, new injection systems produce higher temperatures and pressures at the injector tips. This environment initiates deposit formation at and around the injector tip, which leads to significant power loss and increased smoke generation. Much research has been carried out on injector tip deposits.43–45 With the introduction of ultra low sulfur diesel (ULSD), there has been an ever escalating number of injector deposit incidents in high-pressure common rail (HPCR) fuel systems ( ≥ ∼1500 bar), causing deterioration in both performance and emissions. These deposits tend to be internal and are difficult to remove. Internal diesel injector deposits have become an issue in the field as both fuel and engine technologies have changed. Solubility appears to be the key to internal deposit formation.46

As for the research methodology of deposit formation processes, test rig experiments simulating deposit formation in engine cylinders and engine experiments have been most widely used. Problems will arise when studying engines because of the particularity of the deposits. That is, deposits gathers on the surface of the combustion chamber, and engines must be dismantled to study deposits. On the one hand, a long operation time is required to obtain deposits with measurable thickness, and on the other hand, engines need to be disassembled after operation to collect the deposits, which will definitely influence engine performance in the next operation. Thus, an approximation method makes more sense to study deposits, e.g. a laboratory-scale deposition–corrosion apparatus.47

An indubitable advantage lies in experimental simulation methods, but real engine experiments can provide the properties of deposits more directly and exactly. Thus, more research on deposits is performed on engines, among which the influencing factors on deposit formation constitute the priority of concerns. Below, conclusions are drawn on typical deposit formation on gasoline and diesel engines, and then rules of deposit formation and methods for reducing deposits deformation can be acquired.

sec.title: Diesel engine deposit formation
sec.p: On diesel engines, the directly injected fuel sprays impinge against the combustion chamber walls, resulting in the formation of soot deposits that are unevenly distributed on the surface of the walls depending on the location of spray impingement.

sec.title: Engine influence factors
sec.p: It is easy to understand that engine conditions, combustion chamber geometrical shape and compression ratio, etc. will definitely influence the formation of deposits. These factors have been studied earlier, and a representative study was made by Eilts.25 When investigating the influencing factors of engine deposits, Eilts suggested that deposit formation could be reduced with increase of compression ratio, inlet air, exhaust gas pressure and the load, etc. The reason is that the deposits in the tests described in this work were probably formed mainly from fuel that had been deposited on the wall in the liquid state and evaporated incompletely, and higher temperatures will lead to less fuel deposited. However, with the development of engine technologies and the improvement of fuel and lubricating oil, some new influencing factors also emerge.

sec.title: Influence of exhaust gas recirculation (EGR)
sec.p: EGR is widely used in engines with a notable contribution in reducing NOx emission. Yet, problems also arose with the increase of particulate matter (PM) emission, especially on deposit formation. Singh et al. investigated the influence of EGR on lubricating oil, and comparison was given on the influence of EGR on deposit formation.27 A constant speed, two-cylinder, four-stroke, air cooled, direct-injection (DI), diesel engine (Indec PH2) of 9.7 kW rating coupled with an AC alternator was chosen for this experimental study. Experiments were conducted under normal operating conditions without EGR and with 25% EGR. Engine runs of 96 hours in each condition were completed in 16 test cycles, each of 6 hours, and photographs of the different investigated parts were taken.

Figure 7 shows a comparison between deposits on the piston top with and without EGR, and a comparison between deposits on the cylinder head and injector tip are also given by Singh et al.27 It can be seen clearly that EGR will definitely aggravate the formation of deposits. The reason is that the lower combustion temperature and lower oxygen concentration in the flame enhance soot formation and slower soot oxidation.48 It has been mentioned above that NOx emission will deteriorate with the increase of deposits. The non-volatile parts of the deposits, such as ash, produce higher in-cylinder temperatures, thus leading to higher NOx emissions. Thus, it makes sense to control the EGR rate within a reasonable range to realize low NOx emissions and deposit formation.

caption.p: Carbon deposits on piston crown after 96 h operation.27

sec.p: Distinctive conclusions can be drawn from this study that the usage of EGR will greatly increase the formation of deposits. If the formation of deposits with different ratios of EGR can be investigated and NOx emission results can be monitored, then it is indicative of choosing a proper EGR ratio to achieve a good balance between the emission and deposit formation.

sec.title: Influence of fuel type
sec.p: Diesel and gasoline are complex mixtures of hydrocarbons. New combinations will lead to new types of fuel. The influence of fuel on deposit formation is also important with new types of fuel emerging. Tarkowski et al. studied the influence of fuel on deposit composition.32 Two engines of Leyland type with similar time of running supplied with standard fuel (SO) and ecological fuel of city-diesel (C-D) type produced by Petrochemia Plock (Poland) were chosen to conduct the experiment. By analyzing the composition of deposits from the combustion chambers, the conclusion was made that deposits from the ecological fuel contained four to five times less iron compounds than the standard fuel, which accounted for a smaller attrition of the combustion chamber elements. It must be mentioned that chemical analysis, X-ray diffractograms, Mossbauer absorption and Raman wave-number were used in analyzing the deposits. Figure 8 shows the results of X-ray diffractograms. It can be seen from the figure that the deposits from the engine supplied with improved fuel oil contains less iron, copper, chromium, vanadium and silicon oxides. In addition, the content of phosphorus and sulfur compounds is smaller. Actually, iron compounds in the deposits mainly come from the abrasion of engines. The increase and decrease of the iron compounds in the deposits are shown clearly in the figure. Thus, proper reformed fuel, for example, fuel with a lower T90 temperature, will lead to less deposit formation with decreasing abrasion of engines. Then, a number of benefits will arise from the improvement of fuel, such as lower emissions and better engine performance. Thus, the significance of fuel improvement is obvious.

caption.p: X-ray diffractograms of deposits from a high-pressure engine supplied with different fuels.32

sec.p: Tarkowski studies the influence of fuel type on the composition of deposits with emphasis on the light and heavy elements, particularly iron, in the deposits. The methods proposed in this article provide an instructive guide on the reformation of fuel.

sec.title: Influence of lubricating oil
sec.p: Lubricating oil plays an irreplaceable role in wear reduction and rust prevention in engines. Yet, it was found that lubricating oil also exerted an influence on the formation of deposits.

The influence of lubricating oil on the deposits was thoroughly investigated by Diaby et al.23 They found the influence of lubricating oil degradation on the formation of deposits on the first ring groove using a four-cylinder engine for the formation; characterization of the first ring groove deposits of diesel engine pistons have never been clarified, although the deposits in this area are known to lead to reduced engine durability and performance.23 The grade of the lubricant used for both tests was 5W-30, and the fuel type used was a low sulfur diesel. About 6% of a commercial cerium additive (provided by Rhodia Electronics and Catalysis) in the form of nano-particulate cerium oxide dispersed in an organic solvent was added in the fuel in order to check the contribution of fuel in the deposit formation. Results showed that the deposits, with a structure of cracked varnishes, mainly resulted from the degradation of lubricating oil. Deposits were termed as ‘oily’ and ‘dry’ according to their volatile organic matter content. SEM/energy-dispersive x-ray analysis (EDX), TGA, pyrolysis/gas chromatography/mass spectrometry and FTIR spectroscopy were used to study the physical and chemical characteristics of deposits. Figure 4 showed the results from an SEM. By analyzing the chemical properties of the deposits in first ring groove, a conclusion was drawn that they were mainly carbonaceous and resulted principally from lubricant degradation. These deposits contained a noticeable proportion of metallic elements from the wear of engines.

It can be found from the studies that lubricating oil performs an important role in the formation of deposits. Thus, it will be of great importance to improve lubricating oil, not only in lubrication ability, but also in the function of deposits and emission reduction. For lubricating oil, some is thrown into the combustion chamber at top dead center (TDC), or adheres to the cylinder liner. Just like fuel, some remains on the surface, and may degrade without being burnt or evaporated, and thus contributes to the formation of deposits. On the other hand, lubricating oil may also enter the piston ring groove or piston ring land, and degrade, which makes a large contribution to the major part of the deposit formation here. Particulate substances with incomplete combustion may also gather on the surface of the combustion chamber and contribute to deposit formation, together with fuel and lubricating oil. With the operation of the engines, deposit formation will finally achieve equilibrium.

sec.title: Gasoline engine deposit formation
sec.p: Just like in diesel engines, deposits also form in gasoline engines and many factors will influence the formation process.

sec.title: Influence of fuel additives
sec.p: Fuel additives play a great role in making up for defects and improving the quality of the fuel. However, problems, such as toxic emission, follow the benefits. In addition, the formation of deposits is influenced.49

Zerda et al. investigated the influence of fuel additives on the microstructure of deposits.30 The experiment was conducted in a production spark-ignition 3.1L V6 port fuel injected laboratory test cell engine. Two different types of surfactant additive chemistry were evaluated in this study, one derived from polyether amine (PEA) and one derived from polybutene amine (PBA). At the completion of each test, deposit material was removed by scraping each of the cylinder head regions and piston top regions of the six combustion chambers. The sample material from each respective region of the six cylinders was then mixed together to form one large average sample for that region. The conclusion was drawn that the surface area of deposits decreased with the increase of additive concentration by comparing two types of additives, PEA-1 and PBA-1, at 200 ppm and 400 ppm. A structural comparison of the deposits from the cylinder head, intake valve and piston top was also made, and showed that deposits from the cylinder heads were more porous than those of the piston tops. Likewise, deposits from the intake valves were less porous than those of the combustion chambers. The highlight of the work by Zerda et al.30 was that the surface area of the deposits were evaluated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Dubinin–Radushkevich (DR) theories, and density functional theory was used to evaluate pore size distribution. A representative result is shown in Figure 9.

caption.p: Concentration effect of the additives on the DR/CO2 surface area for cylinder head deposits30.
DR: Dubinin–Radushkevich; PEA: polyether amine-based additive; PBA: polybutene amine-based additive.

sec.p: Zerda et al.30 speculated that the observed dependence of the CCD surface area on the additive package was associated with partial decomposition of the additives in the flame zone. Small fragments may fill up small pores and improve graphene layer alignment.

It can be clearly observed that fuel additives will influence the microstructure of deposits, and properties of deposits will definitely change, which will exert influences on the performance of engines. Thus, an appropriate use of additives will change the structure of deposits, leading to less influence on the normal performance of engines or even to positive effects.16

sec.title: Influence of fuel type
sec.p: Among numerous studies on the influence of fuel types, the most representative article is that of Noma et al.,50 in which the influence of fuel types is investigated in detail, with three different direct-injection spark-ignition (DISI) engines, seven types of fuel and two types of lubricating oil. Photographs of the piston top and other parts after test cycles were given with the different fuel and oil supplied; these provide important references for studying the influence of fuel and oil types on the deposits. Noma et al.50 suggested possible reasons for deposit formation, so it is quite valuable in improving the fuel and engine design to achieve the purpose of reducing deposit deformation.50

Ansomboon et al. also investigated the deposits with seven types of fuel and three types of lubricating oil, and focused on the comparison between the intake-valve deposits (IVDs) and CCDs.51 Some important characteristics of CCDs were proposed. For example, CCDs on the piston top contained more hydrocarbon oil than CCDs on the cylinder head, only with less oxidized and carbonized products, which is conducive to understanding the deposit formation mechanism.

Kelemen et al. investigated the influence of different types of gasoline on the equilibrium of ultimate engine deposits, which is quite meaningful in the researches of deposits in engines under real working conditions.52 In addition, there has been more research carried out by other authors in this regard.53–55

sec.title: Influence of lubricating oil
sec.p: Just as the lubricating oil influences deposits in diesel engines, so does lubricating oil influence the formation of deposits in gasoline engines, and much research similar to the methods of Diaby et al.23 was made to verify the influence of lubricating oil on deposits in gasoline engines.53,56 For example, Ahrenfeldt et al. generated deposits on a 0.48 l single-cylinder high compression ratio spark ignition (SI) engine fueled by synthetic gas. The results of the experiment indicate that the deposits were possibly derived from the lubricating oil.57

sec.title: Injection system
sec.p: Along with the development of technology, DISI engine technology is increasingly used on gasoline engines for the reason that it offers tremendous potential in fuel saving. Port fuel injection engine technology is also widely used for its low manufacturing cost. Deposit formation also differs in the two types of injection systems.

In a DI engine, a concern is its propensity to form deposits on the inlet valve. In extreme cases, these deposits can lead to poor drivability and deteriorating emission performance. Different injection systems lead to different deposit formation mechanisms. However, factors, such as fuel types, lubricating oil types and additives, influence deposit formation in port fuel injection (PFI)51,52 and DI gasoline engines21,58 in the same way. Few studies have been made for different injection systems influenced by the same fuel, lubricating oil or additives, which will lead to a better understanding of deposit formation and methods for reducing deposit formation for different engine types.

In GDI engines, deposits can cause pre and post ignition of the fuel–air mixture, increased occurrence of engine knock, decreased power and increased emissions.59 Deposits formed at the injector tip may cause abnormal fuel injection, which will lead to unsteady engine operation. The way to decrease the deposits here may focus on the reformation of fuel, proper design of injector tips, and control of injector tip temperatures.

sec.title: Effect of fuels on deposit formation in diesel engines
sec.p: Lack of petroleum fuel and restrictions on emissions force people to research alternative fuels or add other substances to existing fuels to achieve better performance. Emulsified diesel fuel and palm oil are two representative innovative measures. However, they also cause deposit formation.28

sec.title: Study on engines fueled with emulsified diesel
sec.p: Water in emulsified diesel fuel plays an important role in reducing combustion chamber temperature and increased momentum of the fuel spray, which enhances the air entrainment into the flame, which will lead to lower NOx and PM emissions. The main intention is to reduce peak temperature in the combustion zone. It is believed that the water could lower the gas temperature by means of water evaporation and thus decreasing the rate of thermal-NOx formation. However, investigations have found that emulsified diesel fuel could also influence the formation of deposits. Husnawan et al. studied deposits in a cylinder head fueled with four types of diesel fuel emulsion samples containing 0%, 5%, 10% and 15% vol. water and 20% palm oil methyl ester (POME).29 Deposits were collected from a single-cylinder DI Yanmar diesel engine after 25 hours for each set of test fuels with a constant speed of 2500 r/min. It was found that less aromatic and less reactive deposits would be formed with an increase of water in the fuel. Four pictures of cylinder heads were also given by Husnawan et al.,29 as shown in Figure 10. It can be found that deposits increase when water in fuel emulsions increases. Emulsified diesel will lower combustion temperature, and thus more deposits will form. TGA was also carried out, from which obvious differences could be found in different deposits.

caption.p: The cylinder head after 25 h operation: (a) 100% OD, (b) 95% OD, (c) 90% OD and (d) 85% OD.29

sec.p: Husnawan et al. investigated the formation of deposits with different diesel fuel emulsion samples.29 Since the increase of water in fuel will aggrandize the formation of deposits, and deposits will lead to higher NOx emission, it is necessary to choose a proper emulsion ratio to realize a relatively lower NOx emission.

sec.title: Studies on engines fueled with palm oil
sec.p: Since petroleum fuel is in short supply, many types of alternative fuel are used in engines. Some problems follow the economic benefits. The formation of deposits in engines is one of them.60

Kalam and Masjuki investigated the emission and deposit characteristics of a small diesel engine when operated on preheated CPO with emulsions with 1%, 2% and 3% water.31 The experiment was conducted on a water-cooled, four-stroke DI Yanmar engine. Conclusions were made that lower emissions of CO, HC and PM and higher NOx emission were found when fueled with preheated CPO, compared with that of OD fuel and CPO emulsified fuels. The main reasons are that preheated CPO reduces its viscosity, improves fuel volatility and produces complete combustion, but increases deposits that cause higher NOx emissions. Deposit characteristics were given by TGA, as shown in Figure 11, which explains the reason why higher NOx emissions were found when fueled with preheated CPO, since preheated CPO increased the fraction of ash deposit. In addition to the physical properties of CPO, one important reason is that CPO is an oxygenated fuel, which includes oxygen in it. The existence of oxygen will reduce the emissions of CO, HC and PM.

caption.p: Deposit composition for various test fuels.31
CPO: crude palm oil; OD: ordinary diesel fuel.

sec.p: Since the use of CPO will lead to lower emissions of HC, CO and PM and higher NOx emissions and more deposits, it is sensible to choose proper types of fuel and after-treatment devices to realize low emissions, as required.

The lack of fossil fuel promotes palm oil to be an important type of alternative fuel. The research of Kalam and Masjuki comprised the characteristics of deposit emission of engine fueled with palm oil and emulsified palm oil and its contrast with diesel.31 It provided an important basis for replacing diesel fuel with palm oil in a better way.

sec.title: Reforming fuel
sec.p: Whether for diesel or gasoline engines, fuel reformation is an important way to improve engine performance and to reduce the emissions. Deposit formation will markedly decrease when fueled with properly reformed fuel, which is favorable for the reduction of deposit formation, and it is a good choice to reform fuel to achieve both lower deposit formation and better engine performance. Gasoline with high aromatic compounds and low T90 adversely affects injector deposits, while CCDs sharply accumulate when T90 exceeds 150 °C.50 One example of reducing deposit formation through diesel fuel reformation is the use of a type of diesel fuel, known as ecological fuel. Deposit formation will decrease, together with lower engine abrasion.37

sec.title: Proper EGR
sec.p: In diesel engines, the existence of EGR will definitely decrease the NOx emission, but the PM in the exhaust will come back into the intake system, which will influence the formation of deposits, which is well illustrated in the study of Singh et al.27 Then, a proper EGR ratio will result in a decrease in both deposits and NOx emissions. The existence of EGR will decrease the oxygen concentration in the intake charge, which reduces reaction temperatures, which leads to reduced NO formation and reduced particulate oxidation. A lower combustion temperature will lead to more deposit formation. PMs caused by incomplete combustion are also an important reason for deposit formation, as this greater number of PMs will offer opportunities for adhering to the surface of the combustion chamber to form deposits.

sec.title: Improving the lubricating oil
sec.p: In diesel engines, it can be clearly seen from the study of Diaby et al. study that the degradation of lubricating oil exerts a great influence on the formation of deposits.23 Deposit formation will decrease by improving the degradability of oil through the proper reformation of lubricating oil or the use of additives, as a large part of the deposits are formed due to the degradation of lubricating oil.

Since the metallic PM in lubricating oil will influence the degradation of oil, another way to decrease deposit formation is to diminish the metallic PM in the lubricating oil in the oil pan. In gasoline engines, it was similarly found that lubricating oil also contributes to the formation of deposits.57

sec.title: Emulsified diesel
sec.p: Husnawan et al. studied deposit deformation in engines when fueled with emulsified diesel with 0%, 5%, 10% and 15% volume of water.29 The results indicated a good way to simultaneously reduce NOx and PM emissions and deposit formation lies in the use of emulsified diesel in proper ratio. Heat absorption of water droplets, when evaporating, will lower combustion temperature. The formation of deposits will increase with decreasing temperature, and this is the reason why deposits increase when water content increases.

sec.title: Additives
sec.p: Fuel and lubricating oil additives are often used to suppress deposits. Detergent additives are used most in fuel to reduce deposit formation. Although how these detergent chemicals act with the CCD structure and other physical properties of the deposits are not well understood, it can be seen through the investigation of two types of additives made by Zerda et al. that the use of additives will diminish the inner surface of deposits and thus decrease the damage of deposits.30 The main function of lubricating oil additives in reducing deposit formation is to increase the anti-degradation of lubricating oil, since the degradation of lubricating oil is the main contribution to deposit formation.23

The proper use of additives, both in type and concentration, can lead to desired emissions and low deposit formation, and this has been verified to be feasible in the case of fuel56 and lubricating oil additives.23

list-item.p: Deposits will exist as long as petroleum fuel is used in engines, and they will influence the performance of engines, such as the deterioration of emissions, decreasing power, etc.
The deposit formation process can be concluded from the influencing factors of fuel and lubricating oil.

Fuel injected into the combustion chamber may not be burnt completely, which adheres onto the surface of the combustion chamber. Part of the fuel gathering on the surface may not evaporate or be burnt, and thus deposits are formed. For lubricating oil, some of it is thrown into the combustion chamber at TDC or adheres to the cylinder liner. Just like fuel, some of it remains on the surface and may degrade without being burnt or evaporated, and thus contributes to the formation of deposits. On the other hand, lubricating oil may also enter the piston ring groove or the piston ring, and degrade, which makes a great contribution to the major part of the deposit formation here. Particulate substances with incomplete combustion may also gather on the surface of the combustion chamber and contribute to deposit formation together with fuel and lubricating oil. With the operation of engines, deposit formation will finally achieve equilibrium.

The existence of deposits is inevitable, but their quantity can be reduced through some proper measures. Conclusions on how to restrain deposit formation could be made from the influencing factors of deposit formation. The use of detergent or surfactant additives in fuel, anti-degradation additives in lubricating oil as well as gasoline with lower T90 temperature and ecological diesel will lead to less deposit formation. Structure change is another method of decreasing the damage to the performance of engines.
